data.text:
There are many reasons why different countries drive on different sides of the road. The most common explanation is that it has to do with the way that horses pulled wagons in old times.

People would walk on the left side of the wagon so they could be closer to the horses and have better control over them. When cars replaced wagons, the habit stuck, and countries continued to drive on the left or right side of the road based on which side their wagons drove on.

Another explanation is that it has to do with swords. Back in the days when people rode horses and fought with swords, it was considered more important to have your sword arm free in case you needed to fight. So, people would walk on the side of the road with their sword arms free.

This explanation seems a bit less likely, but it’s still fun to think about!

Top advice for right-hand drivers

Many of the traffic signs will be in a foreign language, so it’s important to get familiar with them before you start driving.

Right-hand versus Left-hand

Right-hand versus left-hand driving is a conversation that often sparks confusion among drivers, no matter the country.

In left-hand drive countries, such as the United States, the driver sits on the left side of the car, and the steering wheel is also on the left.

Conversely, in right-hand drive countries, such as the United Kingdom, Australia, Indonesia, Japan, India, and Thailand, the driver sits on the right side of the car and looks out from a right-hand steering wheel.
